Suppose that <math display="inline">\theta</math> is a sentence and <math display="inline">\Sigma</math> is a set of formulas. then <math display="inline">\Sigma \cup \theta \vdash \phi</math> if and only if <math display="inline">\Sigma \vdash \left( \theta \to \phi \right)</math>

==Proof==
*<math display="inline">\Leftarrow</math> Assume that <math display="inline">\sigma \vdash \left( \theta \to \phi \right)</math>. Then it's deduction would also show that <math display="inline">\Sigma \cup \theta \vdash \left( \theta \to \phi \right)</math> (appending an unused assumption), and <math display="inline">\Sigma \cup \theta \vdash \theta</math> by the one-line deduction <math display="inline">\theta</math>. Finally by appending the above two deductions, then by our rule of inference for propositional consequence, we can write <math display="inline">\phi</math> as the last line of our deduction. Thus <math display="inline">\Sigma \cup \theta \vdash \theta</math>, as required.
*<math display="inline">\Rightarrow</math> For this direction we will be assuming that <math display="inline">\Sigma \cup \left\{  \theta \right\} \vdash \left( \theta \to \phi \right)</math> and then show that <math display="inline">\Sigma \vdash \left( \theta \to \phi \right)</math>. One technique that would work would be to show that <math display="block">\left\{ \phi : \Sigma \cup \left\{ \theta \right\}\vdash \phi  \right\}\subseteq \left\{ \phi: \Sigma \vdash \left( \theta \to \sigma \right) \right\} \quad \chi</math>, we could do this by appealing to [[Minimal Set of Deducible Formulas|the fact that the set of deductions is minimal]], by using this theorem and setting the set of formulas to be <math display="inline">\Sigma \cup \left\{ \theta \right\}</math>, then we could conclude that <math display="inline">\left\{ \phi : \Sigma \cup \left\{ \theta \right\}\vdash \phi \right\}</math> would be minimal, and if the set <math display="inline">\left\{ \phi: \Sigma \vdash \left( \theta \to \phi \right) \right\}</math> satisfied the 3 requirements in that theorem then we could conclude <math>\chi</math>. 
**Let's verify that our set does satisfy the requirements:
***<math display="inline">\Sigma \subseteq C</math> : 
****If <math display="inline">\sigma \in \Sigma</math> then <math display="inline">\Sigma \vdash \sigma</math> (one line deduction), and then we would also know that by our rules of inference for propositional consequence; <math display="inline">\Sigma \vdash \left( \theta \to \sigma \right)</math>
***<math display="inline">\theta \in C</math>, it is, because <math display="inline">\Sigma \vdash \theta \to \theta</math> is a tautology.
***<math display="inline">C</math> is closed under our rules of inference.
****Propositional Consequence: Suppose that <math display="inline">\gamma_{1}, \gamma_{2},  \dots ,\gamma_{n - 1},\gamma_{n} \in C</math> and that <math display="inline">\phi</math> is a propositional consequence of <math display="inline">\left\{ \gamma_{1}, \gamma_{2},  \dots ,\gamma_{n - 1},\gamma_{n} \right\}</math> then we have to show that <math display="inline">\phi \in C</math>. We note that <math display="inline">\left( \theta \to \phi \right)</math> is a propositional consequence of the set <math display="block">\left\{ \left( \theta \to \gamma_{1}\right), \left( \theta \to \gamma _{2} \right), \ldots, \left( \theta \to \gamma_{n} \right) \right\}</math> To see why, we would first apply [[Formula Conversion from FOL to PL|the algorithm]] and then show that <math display="inline">\left( \theta_{P} \to \phi_{P} \right)</math> is a propositional consequence of <math display="block">\left\{ \left( \theta_P \to \gamma_{1P}\right), \left( \theta_P \to \gamma _{2P} \right), \ldots, \left( \theta_P \to \gamma_{nP} \right) \right\}</math> But that's the case, because assume <math display="inline">t</math> is a truth assignment function such that makes each of the formulas in the above set true <math display="inline">\left( \alpha \right)</math> 
*****If <math display="inline">\bar{t}\left(\theta_{P}\right)=F</math> and everything is vacuously true
*****If <math display="inline">\bar{t}\left(\theta_{P}\right)=T</math> and then by <math display="inline">\alpha</math>, we know that <math display="inline">\forall i \in \left[ n \right], \bar{t}\left(\gamma_{iP}\right) = T</math> but <math display="inline">\phi_{P}</math> is a propositional consequence of<math display="inline">\left\{ \gamma_{1}, \gamma_{2},  \dots ,\gamma_{n - 1},\gamma_{n} \right\}</math> and so <math display="inline">\bar{t}\left(\phi_{P}\right)=T</math> and thus <math display="inline">\bar{t}\left(\theta_{P} \to \phi_{P}\right)=T</math> as required.
***Quantifier rules: Suppose that <math display="inline">\psi \to \phi</math> is in <math display="inline">C</math> and <math display="inline">x</math> is not free in <math display="inline">\psi</math>. we want to show that <math display="inline">\left( \psi \to \forall x \phi \right)</math> is an element of <math display="inline">C</math>. That is <math display="block">\Sigma \vdash \left[ \theta \to \left( \psi \to \forall x \phi \right) \right]</math>
****Since <math display="inline">\psi \to \phi \in C</math> then we know that <math display="inline">\Sigma \vdash \left[ \theta \to \left( \psi \to \phi \right) \right]</math> and then <math display="inline">\Sigma \vdash \left( \theta \land \psi  \right) \to\phi</math> is a propositional consequence . Then by our quantifier rule (the one we are proving a certain property about right now), we verify that <math display="inline">x</math> is not free in <math display="inline">\theta</math> but that is true by the assumption that <math display="inline">\theta</math> is a sentence.
*****So we get <math display="inline">\Sigma \vdash \left( \theta \land \psi  \right)\to \forall x \phi</math> and using our propositional consequence in the opposite order as the original usage, we have <math display="inline">\Sigma \vdash \left[ \theta \to \left( \psi \to \forall x \phi \right) \right]</math> so <math display="inline">\left(  \psi \to \forall x \phi  \right) \in C</math>. The existential proof is similar.
*So we have shown that <math display="inline">C</math> contains <math display="inline">\theta</math>, all the elements of <math display="inline">\Sigma</math> and <math display="inline">\Lambda</math> and we finally know that <math display="inline">C</math> is closed under our rules of inference. So we are done.
